review_title: Some of the most passionate/smart people I’ve ever met
pros: I get to work with some of the most passionate and smart people I have ever met. The company is really ahead in regards to trying new things and maintaining a more relaxed culture while taking the work we do here very seriously. Senior leadership has been making changes to diversify across the org. This will take time, but appreciate the commitment and momentum in making some serious changes.
cons: We do so much and move really really fast. This means it is never boring, but from a support operations side, there are times where I wish we would or could slow down and focus on getting our larger processes in place to create efficiencies and make sure we are strategic.

pros: It is a well-organized organization with excellent values
cons: Short term as it was for 5 years only

review_title: They stay true to their values
pros:
Counterpart International is an organization with heart. They keep their people happy while maintaining their goal of coming up with novel solutions to real world problems on a massive scale. 

While I’ve been disappointed in the past by similar organizations’ lack of follow through and inconsistent values, Counterpart has so far delivered in all aspects of their promises.
cons: The only con is that the work is demanding, and oftentimes it’s hard to find solutions that address the complex issues we’re trying to tackle in their entirety. That said, we’re taking necessary steps in the right direction.

review_title: Had a lot of say in projects
pros: This was one of my favorite jobs to date! I was involved in many different projects, and many of my ideas were utilized when we were developing projects, even when I was still the new kid on the block. It opened up a whole new world of possibilities for me.
cons: While CI had its weaknesses, I still believe that they were doing the best they could given all the complications we dealt with. With that, I can’t say that there were any cons.

review_title: Not such a great place to work
pros: Ability to work relatively unsupervised and granted a wide range of authority. International travel opportunities. I was lucky because I had a great supervisor who encouraged my career, but when he was forced out the quality of life at Counterpart took a nose dive.
cons: Aloof senior management. Lots of pom pom cheer leading rhetoric by management about CPI's vision/values but rarely do they follow through with action. I left because my sr. management was ignoring our team for months but then got all bent out of shape when I scheduled an overseas trip, which I had been planning for months, which I was ordered to do! Also, out of fear of a USG audit, the organization cares more about bureaucratic paperwork compliance then on quality programming. They're more concerned with checking bureaucratic boxes

pros: Best place I’ve ever worked! The work environment is vibrant, people share similar values and are supportive of one another, managers care about employee well-being, the organization operates with utmost integrity, there are plenty of learning opportunities, and it’s a ton of fun!
cons: While we share many of the same challenges that most non-profit organizations face, we have a way of coming together to get through them that makes all the difference.

pros: Good work culture and environment for growth
cons: Too some extent there was micro management of employees

pros: Pleasant atmosphere, kind people, and plenty of learning opportunities. Leadership keeps the team motivated. Benefits are astoundingly good.
cons: Not sure when I’ll be able to more up the company ladder.

pros: I enjoyed working for Counterpart International because I felt like the work I was doing was making a difference. They take their mission very seriously, and provide employees with the tools they need to accomplish their assignments.
cons: It was a lot of work for a small company. One person’s inability to complete their work on time affected the rest of the team.

pros: Great place to gain experience. They assign interns meaningful tasks. You gain a lot of insight into the business by working with various departments. Staff was willing to offer assistance as needed. I would definitely recommend this company to anyone who wants to work for nonprofits.
cons: I didn’t notice any cons while interning there.

pros: I was amazed by everyone’s commitment to the company’s mission! It’s rare to find a workplace where everyone’s principles align so nicely, which was an essential part of our success.
cons: In two words: inconsistent priorities.

pros:
Great place to gain industry experience

CEO was involved and spent a lot of time speaking with staff members and finding ways to improve our tactics

Collaborative team environment
cons: Lots of great ideas but not enough planning to seamlessly execute them

pros:
Easy to learn the ropes even if you don’t have previous experience
Management is understanding and respectful of our personal time
Younger staff members bring new ideas to the table
Job stability is a non-issue as work is always available
cons: Pay isn’t great for the area

review_title: Understands the value of its people
pros: Counterpart International really believes that its people are its most important asset. They are constantly working to improve benefits (which are already quite good), staff development and inclusion.
cons: Counterpart International doesn't believe in standardized approaches. Every problem is different and they try to create an environment that leave staff free to find new solutions. That's great but can be very frustrating for people who crave clarity or who are uncomfortable with ambiguity.

pros: Progressed in my career as a result of working for Counterpart.
cons: Difficult to maintain good work/life balance.

pros: Mostly worked independently however managers were supportive when they were needed
cons: Not the highest paying job out there

pros: Counterpart International strives to constantly improve and expand its impact. Management tries to do the right thing by all. You will be challenged and asked to think outside the norm.
cons: The pace of change can sometimes be hard to keep up with, particularly when balancing the difficult job of moving programs forward in very difficult environments.

pros: Excellent colleagues, strong in advocacy, even stronger in on the ground design, implementation and impact, truly caring and clear eyed, morally centered, supportive of staff, truly making conscious strides in gender and inclusivity.
cons: With so much change through constantly improving systems, field staff are often overwhelmed trying to keep up with all the new initiatives, while also keeping up with existing programs.

pros: Good compensation & benefits, terrific management, intelligent coworkers, rewarding work
cons: Don’t have anything significant enough to report

review_title: Working for a company that genuinely cares
pros: Humanitarian work is fulfilling in itself. Working with a company that cares makes it even better.
cons: No hand-holding from leadership. Must be self-motivated.

pros: Good programs that truly helped the people we were serving.
cons: Needed to take on responsibilities outside of usual scope of work in assigned position.

pros: My experience was completely positive!
cons: The reality is less glamorous than the ideal.

pros: Friendly atmosphere, dedicated colleagues, excellent leadership
cons: Can’t say for sure since I no longer work here

pros: there are lots of pros about working here and I found it to be a very stimulating and positive work environment with people who are devoted to changing the world
cons: wish the pay were much better

pros: A brilliant past, some good projects (not sure how many of those remain to this day), the feeling of "doing good" (?)
cons:
Very high turnover. The incoming CEO staffed the place with friends and former coworkers, at times regardless of capacity. Titles were given away like cookies. 

She created a "cult of herself" and her minions tend obliged. A very "Yes Ma'am" culture. I doubt there is any staff that has been there longer than 2-3 years now.

Their version of diversity has been hiring only women. You can see that as a positive until you realize that... is not diversity!

pros:
Rewarding work
Mission driven organization
cons: Lots of change, but full transparency as to why

pros: Great benefits. The mission of the organization is a good motivation to work. The environment will depend on your post.
cons: Depends on everyone doing their part.

pros:
-Strong company culture
-Inclusive
-Good camaraderie amongst teammates
-Interesting work
-Fair pay, especially for a startup
cons:
-Weak organizational structure
-Sub-par benefits

pros: Great office environment, lots of opportunities for growth, the employees truly believe in the mission of the organization
cons: Sometimes can feel a bit cliquey, compensation is not always commensurate with employees experience or skill

pros:
Humble and extremely talented employees 
Teams are collaborative and don't appear to work in silos 
Budget conscious and strategic leadership 
Open and honest communication with all staff 
Diversity and inclusion prioritized 
First-rate benefits
cons: Occasionally clunky tech, but very responsive tech support

pros: I loved the commitment of employees and management.
cons: There's not a lot of room to grow.

pros: Looks like the new management is able to improve the work environment
cons: The history of extremely bad management is massive. Hope the new management is able to overtake this history.

review_title: Enjoy the work and future prospects
pros:
Counterpart's mission and approaches in international development . 
Smart and passionate staff.
A comfortable work environment. 
Consistent effort to improve the organization's performance. .
cons: Work-life balance - smaller team with a lot of work. While the organization is trying to tackle this issue, the change is slow and sometimes efforts feel disingenuous.

pros: great mission, easy access to office
cons: none, wish we can do more

pros:
The people! We were Diverse and Inclusive before it became a trend.
It was a human organization that appreciated people and elevated them, gave them purpose and brought results worldwide. 
Counterpart was a melting pot of people and a model organization in empathy and staff care.
cons:
The founders would be disappointed in today’s Counterpart and especially its CEO.
Absolute failure to understand the little people, those who are not from the aristocratic side of town. Technically unqualified and detached from reality, unable to even show up to the office without making her immediate crew slave over logistics and infinite schedule changes. 
The CEO just wants the title and we sure miss the previous CEO and COO. 
The reputation within the industry took a hit as well so you won’t learn much here.
No resources for staff development or incentives, just overload and overtime.

pros: Strong technical expertise; respectful staff; engaging and proactive HR
cons: Less support for administrative tasks

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-Remote work
-Interesting projects (what's left of them)
cons:
As Counterpart shrinks in size, so does it's legacy. At the helm is a CEO who cares only about looking good but is so disconnected with reality that she doesn't see the hypocrisy of her words and actions internally and externally.  She surrounds herself with senior staff who not only mostly look like her but say "yes" to every off the cuff wish that she dreams up. Mediocracy is the standard for the directors. High turn-over has been normalized. Hiring/promoting incompetent directors and associate directors to further support a failing organization is status quo and a recipe to demoralize remaining staff. Pretending that the organization is the best it's ever been is at best delusional, at worst, borderline criminal. It is so top heavy that consultants do majority of the work at the home office. 

The CEO continues to tolerate directors who mute staff and strip them of any decison making power.  There is no room for others...in every sense of the word. If you value integrity and inclusion, Counterpart is not for you.

review_title: Professional Development Opportunities, Empathetic Leadership & Unique Projects
job_title: Mid Level Management in Irving, TX
pros: Interesting, dedicated group of co-workers, supportive and encouraging culture. As a small shop, this provides opportunity for individuals to learn and be exposed to various aspects of programming and/or business development, given autonomy and trust and able to gain experiences quickly. Supportive of professional development and internal growth with open communication about personal goals and objectives. Empathetic leadership that cares about their teams as individuals. Driven professionals eager to contribute. Does unique and impactful work globally.
cons: Small shop results in having to juggle multiple priorities; Somewhat cumbersome oversight processes/procedures.

pros: I liked the diversity and positive culture at Counterpart. Most employees are highly qualified and nice. The CEO and CFO are wonderful people. The teams in various countries are very strong which results in successful projects implementation.
cons: It is like most NGOs, there is turnover and busy schedule.

pros: Culture, mission, diversity, inclusion, hybrid
cons: Training is not seamless for on boarding

pros: Great, friendly atmosphere for the most part. The organization has a long and rich history and it carries its own identity and mission.
cons: Sometimes management allows people unfamiliar with the culture or industry a stronger voice than they deserve, and this can become disempowering to the organization, its mission, and the culture. In addition, Counterpart needs to focus more on on improving program implementation.

job_title: Finance Officer in Crystal City, VA
pros: A good learning place, specially for newbies in international development industry
cons: Selfish CEO, work and personal life balance can't be found

review_title: Counterpart has been in transition and has stabilitized
pros: Positive and supportive culture; smart, high-performing, and friendly team; leadership that cares
cons: Senior management have been trying to improve overall work-life balance, however, many staff members still have a lot on their plate.

pros: Management good! Co-workers are very nice
cons: Not too many new projects

pros: Organization undergoing tremendous change. Good flexible hours, benefits.
cons: Too much change in too little time. Trying to find their way.

job_title: Chief of Party in Washington, DC
pros: I was able to travel and I was feeling useful
cons: Counterpart is a great company to anyone who want to work in the international development industry but lack of opportunities for carrier growth.

review_title: Great mission driven organization with strong strategic leadership
pros: Counterpart has a strong and compliant financial management function led by an astute leader
cons: Counterpart should continue on improving systems for operational efficiencies

pros: Mission driven non-profit that does good work overseas. Strong community and team vibe - you're treated like family.
cons: On the smaller side in the industry, so there is need/opportunity to be a generalist and tackle things outside of one's comfort zone.

pros: Benefits are too bad, good mission
cons: People are overworked and under appreciated

pros: People are dedicated and involved
cons: procedures are very heavy and tedious

pros: great learning experience. Overworking employees
cons: Terrible salary . You work more and get paid less

pros:
- A lot of camaraderie  between mid level to lower management staff.
- Interesting programs 
- Decent benefits - work from home options
- Does excellent work around the globe
cons:
- Toxic culture at HQ; the CFO has called it a 'culture of fear' in all staff meetings -- more than once. 
- HIGH TURNOVER - Among lower staff; higher staff who upset the powers that be are fired - or I'm sorry "_____ took a new opportunity and resigned" 
- Staff knowledge not taken seriously- Be hired as a consultant because as a staffer your life experience and global knowledge is NOT valued if you are just "staff"
-0 Staff Development - Because staff isn't a priority, why would the company invest in their skills?
- Pay is low and Recognition is beneath experience - Have Senior Program Officer experience? At Counterpart you will be forced into a Program Officer (or lower) position, while still be expected to operate a SPO level. 
- No policies in place for staff engagement, retention, or complaints
- No diversity of opinion - If you're not a company favorite, keep your opinion to yourself. Even if you're a favorite, be quiet, you don't know, you're not informed. Sit down. 
- No diversity at the top - For an INGO, there is 0 diversity at the top; Some VPs/C-Suite members don't even have ID experience - you can see the lack of diversity in how the company talks about itself 
- Can't win any new bids - future career opportunities are questionable (if you can stick around that long.)

review_title: Could be a great place, but lacks grounding and proper management
pros: great field teams--they make the organization what it is. new COO has brought in a new style of leadership. pockets of cool technical work around the projects. internal promotions are prevalent and positive
cons: HQ staff are scarred from half decade of constant change and transition. leadership sidelined long-serving members of organization. HR services are horrible. constantly changing, no explanation. HR leadership is absent. 3 CFOs over a 5 year stretch. one worse than the other and the scars are all over the organization. executives don't practice the values of the organization. starting with CEO, all the way down.

review_title: They've been hemorrhaging talent the past year!
pros: Depending on which team you work on, work-life balance can be good, and family-friendly management allow for maternity leave and an understanding that someone has to leave at a specific time to pick up kids at childcare/school.
cons: Talent has been jumping ship the past two years. There was rapid unsustainable growth a few years ago (with rampant overspending), and then a rift to let people go. Many staff members feel overburdened with no help in sight to even replace people who have left. Morale is completely in the dumps. There is no sense of leadership whatsoever. Managers are hired or promoted with zero training in management. The organization always seems to be fixing problems of the past, while creating new problems that will have to be fixed a few years from now. The organization has been, and continues to suffer, with a personal identity crisis, not clear on who it wants to be. And, finally, HR is the worst I've ever witnessed, completely non-transparent, and creates and amends policies ad hoc to suit their needs (or the needs of a few favored employees) without ever even conveying changes to existing policies. This is a serious hurdle for any advancement in the organization. HR offers no training whatsoever, is biased, and perceived as non-trustworthy.

pros: U get the chance to evolve in the career
cons: The local management was poor

pros:
My colleagues are awesome. Collegial fun spirit. 
Commuter benefits: Metro cost-share is within the DC norms.
Remote work one day per week if you want to which is a plus for me
Can work from home if emergency or bad weather
The work we do in the world - try to build capacity for local organizations and actors.
Very diverse group of people (except in management) - all countries and languages represented...feels like the U.N
cons:
Management: C suites and VPs : out of touch with the reality of the staff at HQ and field offices.
Questionable decisions all across, consistent nepotism and racially-based favorites games, inability to hold anyone in management accountable. 
VPs are all untouchable no matter what they do or how they act. 
Big talkers, big plans...but little positive impact on the people who truly do the work. 
The Values are another Big Management spending project but everyone is scared to speak up - retaliation is the norm. Management does not follow its own values. 
Turnover and overnight firings are standard practise. 
Junior staff are equivalent to interns: overworked and under-appreciated.

review_title: Not the best place to work !
pros: There are very handful of peoples with extensive workign experiences in international development world from whom you can learn several things.
cons: The managment is undoubtedly the worst I have ever come across in my career. Most of the managers got promoted instantly without having any skills or knowledge of how to communicate with your staff and more importantly supervise juinor staff. They treat you as if you know nothing and yet expect you to be a professional in everything. The program development is the worst in the organization where there's no teamwork effort and no courtesy of learning and leading. The organization may give opportunities to international staff in their local offices by promoting new professionals, but in HQ- there is no chance of learning and be appreciated of what you do everyday.

pros: There are many hardworking, experienced and dedicated individuals on the Program team.
cons:
-HR had trouble filling positions in a timely manner, which caused the workload to be unbearable at times for program staff trying to balance additional responsibilities of recently departed staff members
-Executive level reviews salaries and increases were inconsistent and they regularly asked staff to justify increases (although staff were taking on substantial increases in responsibilities)
-the disconnect between program teams and the management/executive teams creates roadblocks to effective management of programs
-Compliance team was severely understaffed and not able to provide the appropriate support to process high level contracts, grants, and grant award amendments in a timely manner
- Management staff in many cases did not know how to manage both programs and individual people which led to many departures

review_title: Not pleasant. The senior level officers were very unprofessional towards junior and entry level staff.
pros:
Moderate benefit package.
Good opportunity to travel
Strong Excutive Team- but often times they are not aware of things/issues that exist among junior-mid level staff.
cons:
The senior level officers were extremly unprofessional and not knowlegeable about USAID rules and regulations. The HR is not supportive and most of the times, they attempt to find or refer to company policies which has not been established yet. In terms of hiring ex-pats and DC hire, the HR plays a crucial role. However, when it comes to hiring TCNs and local staff, all matters handled by staff who are not HR professionals and have no background in recruitment, salary negotiations and employee relations. 

Above all, none of the staff practices employee confidentiality. During my employment, I came across with many confidential and personal information that were avaialable for anyone to see !!

pros: The Counterpart mission is clear - empower leaders and communities to work in partnership with government and private sector to address their greatest challenges. I am passionate about this mission and enjoy working with all my colleagues to achieve this. The leadership at CPI makes a lot of space for me to work, take initiative and achieve our goals. The field teams are strong and a great asset. Finance, IT, Comms and HR are all great supporters of mission.
cons: A few colleagues fall back on old habits learned when Counterpart was smaller, with fewer resources and able to function with very few systems. A few teams choose to compete rather than collaborate.

pros: Like many international development organizations, Counterpart has dedicated staff. Flexible schedules (telecommuting) is also available to some staff, depending on team.
cons: Senior leadership has changed significantly in the past couple years, with some coming from outside the industry (consulting, private sector). It seems that each has his/her own vision for the organization. Counterpart has also restructured, leading to many staff being let go. This change management was not handled in a transparent manner. Communication trickles from the top down on a mostly ad hoc basis. When policies change, they are also not communicated well across the organization, which leads to some tension across business units. Turnover is very high among junior and mid-level staff. Opportunities for professional development varies dramatically across the organization.

review_title: My experience at Counterpart provided opportunity for growth, but not for all and not in a direct, well-understood path.
pros: Professional relationships with colleagues, international travel experience, reasonably good benefits (but also keeping in mind it is an NGO).
cons:
Management - lack of communication of vision and direction of firm
Turnover - Many people leaving for a multitude of reasons that are not fully understood
Compensation - Pay is relatively non-competitive when compared to other development firms, and the broader market as a whole. This is true at all levels of management.

review_title: Not a good place to work!
pros: Some good people with truly good objectives try their best, but these are all low level people who can't affect change.
cons:
So many cons to list, but here is a summary:
-CEO inept, cold and indecisive 
-COO harsh, two-faced and belittling
-CFO never around, and his second in command is extremely toxic, back-stabbing, and vindictive
-The company and execs pride themselves on doing good work, but the company is inefficient, ineffective and a waste of US government funding
-health insurance options are horrible and expensive - even though HR spends lots of time trying to convince the entire staff that it's not so bad (but everyone knows we were just being lied to)
-Ridiculously hard to get a promotion based on merit, but some get them based on butt kissing

pros:
The colleagues are great, mission-oriented, they care about the work. Working with colleagues outside of HQ/field-based is great and fulfilling. 
Commute is good and the ability to telework or do summer compressed work week is a plus, mainly if you need to take care of personal business. 

They recently started doing more culture events like ice cream socials which is a nice break but more is needed to glue back  fragmented staff.
cons:
This is not my first NGO but this has been the least enjoyable.Low morale and  high turnover because staff are not motivated and the same people keep getting the accolades regardless of how badperformers or managers they are. We rarely see the CEO and even less hear from her on how the company is truly doing. Recent start ups have been problematic - when managers make it a point to violate policies, demean anyone who is not above them, manipulate situations and create conflicts to advance their own agenda, then nobody is safe and no work is engaging when Directors make it a point to abuse their authority and dismiss others. 
Until the company addresses the problem of bad managers/Directors, there is no hope. 

Professional Development is non-existent. There is no advancement and even less prospect for learning and acquiring new skills despite the CEO's claims of being a learning CEO which clearly shows how detached and disconnected she is from the staff. 

Merit increases are minimal but some few are given high raises over and over because some managers are not good at assessing and rating. 

Non programmatic departments such as IT and HR seem to be on overload all the time and the self-service we heard about has not occured yet.

pros:
- Benefits: Employer contributes 6% which is not bad. Transportation benefits is good. Health benefit is average in the industry. 

- Pay: Annual performance increase is average 3- 5%, sometimes with a good bonus  which is not common at a non-profit.

- The new CFO and CEO are very personable and know most employees by name.
- Most memorable was the CEO calling all staff meetings, where employees would breakout into groups to discuss and contribute ideas to the company's 5 year strategic goals.  So employees had a say in how they want to see the company grow in the next 5 years. 

- The workforce is smart, diverse and friendly. 

- Work hours and strain had improved a lot by the time I left the company and they seemed to be focusing on improving work life balance. 
- Telecommuting at least once a week and can choose compressed work week in the summer (You could take off every other Friday if you worked 9 hours on the other days) instead of telecommuting which was an awesome benefit.  
- Work is challenging. I learned a lot there because I was doing a lot more, and had a different responsibilities vs at other companies.
cons:
- Benefits could be better.  but you only get 20 days "PTO" - which is sick + vacation days, and 40 hours rollover = not enough! They first changed the  rollover to 0 days, and a lot of employees lost their vacation days. A year after this change, perhaps after many complaints, changed to 40 hours rollover. 
- Not too many growth opportunities, and salaries are low.  
- High Turnover
- Most staff are afraid to talk to the new VP, for fear of being fired. 
- I have also heard some of the Directors shouting at the field staff 
- Win rate is going down, so no new money coming in = job future is uncertain

review_title: Great mission and great people.  Yeah, the sector is changing fast, so Counterpart is going through some big changes.
pros: Like the direction we are going.  I love the people.  Very family friendly. I see lots of opportunities for me. I like that some of the weaker folks have left - yea, they didn't like the changes.
cons: Hit a rough patch in 2013.  It seems to have made the organization stronger - but still early days.  We lost some good people - very sad - but also lost some dead wood.

review_title: Good place to start a career, but glad I'm out now
pros:
Young staff are exposed to a lot of different work which beefs up the resume. 
Lots of opportunities to get involved in different teams and projects.
Generally friendly environment.
cons:
Interns used as program assistants (with the full responsibility that entails) and as receptionists!
Overall low morale due to layoffs, lack of transparency from upper management, and lack of direction set for the organization.

review_title: High Turnover, Decreasing Benefits and Management Issues
pros:
Good place for interns or entry-level professionals seeking career in international development
Some flexibility in working schedule depending on manager and department
International staff representing countries from around the globe
cons:
High turnover at all levels
Lack of clear strategic vision for organization and connection to everyday work
Diminishing benefits to employees
Lack of transparency in decision-making processes

pros: Some good managers and directors to work with and learn from
cons:
Terrible employee benefits 
Some employees are sponsored for work due to nepotism because they are liked by the their department head where you can find better employees in the DMV area
Some directors don't let the junior or mid level staff to even talk or express their views
The systems in place (finance, travel, procurement, documents storing and etc)sucks and every year IT comes with new systems which they themselves don't know about it
Always add more tasks on junior or lower level staff however the project managers or directors don't know how to implement the projects

pros: Strength in civil society, governance, and organizational development work.
cons: Internal systems poorly established. Generally a bit dysfunctional -- some senior team members lead work well, but the organization is not well coordinated in its efforts. They have a decent foothold in governance and civil society, but there's less there than meets the eye in terms of programming scale and portfolio.

pros: Counterpart is sitting on a great mandate, which could support civil society in many developing countries
cons:
My time with Counterpart has been the worst in my career, working with more than 10 companies and non-profits. High staff turnover seems to be a deliberate policy with senior management pulling the rug under field offices, experience staff and projects. Senior management is not capable of supporting staff development or retaining talent. 
There is no project management system in place and everything hinges on loads of email exchanges. The culture and work environment is sick and does not deserve the loyalty and commitment from devoted staff. At least, devotion is not acknowledged or returned.

pros: Some really great hardworking people, especially at lower levels.
cons: Management does not value talent, leading to extremely high turnover. Refusal to promote talented people, at all levels, leads to hiring less-than-ideal people from the outside. Managers that value the talent below them are unable to promote or hold onto staff even when they want to. HR services non existent at all levels, including support for top-quality recruitment, managing personnel issues, and responding to inquiries or issues with payroll and benefits. Behavior bordering on the unethical is ignored/swept under the rug by management. Lack of training for management teams. Lack of transparency from the top.

pros: It was a good place to work overall, the projects were fairly interesting and I felt rewarded for good work.
cons: At the time, the organization was in a lot of flux and there were constantly new initiatives coming down from senior management but not enough follow-through to make them work. Also, I was giving very little training to begin with.

job_title: Senior Program Officer in Arlington, VA
pros: really great people and a good mix of new blood and long-timers. a bunch of cool stuff happening in the organization. staff are committed and different from other organizations because they stick around for more than just the money etc.
cons: benefits aren't great, and HR services are non existent.

review_title: Typical Government Contractor interested mainly in maximizing expenses
job_title: Senior Program Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Good Healthcare plan. Retirement plan is useful only if your contract is extended beyond 2 years.
cons: Heavy on senior management. No commitment to projects that might entail innovation or risk. No experience or interest in technology projects. Non-existent IT support. Most decisions driven by an incompetent and disorganized finance and compliance department. Overspends on overhead while frugal on field work. Incapable of managing non-HQ-based employees.

review_title: Good people, dwindling benefits, bad management
job_title: International Program Analyst in Arlington, VA
pros: Good place to start your career, but then the best move is to get out.
cons: High turnover, removed a lot of benefits with almost no warning, no raises, lot of fights. Some people are never there, which could be a good thing if that's up your alley

pros: The team I worked with was really nice and we worked together very well. Really good low level staff that all work very hard.
cons: Teams do not work well with each other. Other departments had serious trouble from their top people leading to an extremely high turnover.

review_title: Organization suffers from instability and ongoing flux
pros: Generally, co-workers are great - very supportive, dedicated, and willing to work long hours to achieve results
cons: Pick a direction and stick with it - constantly changing and reorganizing the structure adds unnecessary stress and confusion.

pros:
great mission
staff are passionate about the work they do
cons: HR and management challenges. Some staff in managerial positions lack management skills and experience. Staff are overall dissatisfied.

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Arlington, VA
pros: Great location. Junior staff are very good and deserve to work at a better place.
cons: Toxic work environment with an inept Human Resource department that does not seem to deal with the myriad bad managers it has to deal with. CEO runs the organization with a coolness that chills the soul. Upper management is absolutely inept.

pros: Many programs are good in general.
cons: Senior management was not accountable. I was hired for program management, I ended being asked to do fundraising .
